Award.AwardTitle: A New Paradigm for Multiflow in MC-MR Wireless Networks: Theoretic Foundations And Practical Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The multiflow problems in wireless networks address the transportation of traffic demands by multiple end-to-end communication requests at the maximum capacity. State-of-the-art methods of solving the multiflow problems require an excessive amount of computational resources, and consequently often prove unusable in practice. This project explores a completely new paradigm for multiflow problems in multi-channel multi-radio wireless networks and develops much faster and simpler practical algorithmic solutions that offer quantified trade-off between accuracy and efficiency. The new paradigm has wide applications in domains beyond wireless networks, and serves as a basis for interesting future projects on network capacity and cross-layer design and optimizations in wireless networks.

Due to the cross-layer nature, multiflow problems in wireless networks pose unique and significant challenges. Characterizing computational hardness and strategies for resolving achievable approximation bounds have been the priority in existing studies of multiflow problems in wireless networks. In fact, state-of-the-art approximation algorithms for multiflow problems in wireless networks are all centralized and rely upon traditional linear programming (LP) methods exclusively. However, these traditional LP methods require an inordinate amount of running time and memory even for a moderate sized input, and consequently they often prove unusable in practice. Furthermore, the centralized nature of traditional LP methods make them unsuitable for developing distributed network protocols. This project explores a new paradigm for multiflow problems in multi-channel multi-radio wireless networks that is different from the prevailing LP-based paradigm, and develops practical algorithmic solutions that are much faster and simpler.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multiflow problems are one of the most fundamental problems in both wired networks and wireless networks. Due to the cross-layer nature, multiflow problems in wireless networks are significantly harder than their counterparts in wired networks and have received much research interest over the past decade. Prior to this project, state-of-the-art approximation algorithms for multiflow problems in wireless networks are all centralized and resorted to the traditional linear programming (LP) methods exclusively. However, those traditional LP methods can require an inordinate amount of running time and memory even for a moderate sized input, and consequently they often prove unusable in practice.  This project develops two completely new paradigms for multiflow problems in multi-channel multi-radio wireless networks which are radically different from the prevailing LP-based paradigm, and develops practical algorithmic solutions which are much faster and simpler. The first paradigm reduces the multiflow problems in general wireless networks to sequence of a sequence of computations of shortest paths and independent sets. The second paradigm reduces the multiflow problems in various wireless networks having explicit polynomial approximate capacity regions to sequence of a sequence of computations of shortest paths only. Both paradigm offers nice trade-off between accuracy in terms the approximation bound and efficiency in terms of the running time, and are much simpler and faster. In addition, this project discovers explicit polynomial approximate capacity regions achieved by efficient link scheduling algorithms in various wireless networks. These  polynomial approximate capacity regions have wide algorithmic applications in  maximizing networking capacities.
